text:
Programmer get really messed up about licences.
The thing most miss is that intellectual property is a civil court matter.
And the civil court looks at a license  (or a contact in general) in a way that is nothing like how a programmer (or a interpreter) looks at a program.
It's not _"execute this from beginning to end. This is all your input. If you step outside of what is possible arbitrary bad things might happen."_.
There are a whole like of extra things considered.
A lot of context, a bunch of reasonableness, proof of damages etc and precedent.
(And in many cases without precedent we don't really know what would happen. And there is very little precedent for open source litigation. Most of what there is is GPL vs commercial entities directly taking code)
IANAL, but AIUI it's way less straight forward, and also way more forgiving and sensible than people think.

text: absolutely: thinking that licenses work like programs is too strict in some ways and not strict enough in other ways

text: this is a “too strict” case: yes, technically someone may have violated copyright law, but any judge is going to look at this situation and cut someone slack for clearly trying to follow the law in good faith
